section.title: Description
section.p: This tool supports an LCM friendly mechanism for delivering cumulative urgent file-replacement patches. These patches provide file replacement in emergency patch situations and critical updates to custom plugins. The patch can include files that may be file-replaced and that are not localized, such as XML files, tools, scripts, etc, but also jar files. This type of patch is cumulative and includes the content of all previous patches since the base version. The base version in this case is the most recent version deployed via the standard software update procedure.
Any update that involves the following are delivered by the In-Service-Upgrade (ISU) procedures. This tool cannot be considered for updates that include:

li.p: CE Docker images on Common Services nodes
Ansible scripts (which are outside of the VNF)
CSF/3rd party patches that cannot be file-replaced (e.g. if they require RPM updates)
any incompatible updates where new software cannot run at the same time as the old software

section.p: This type of patch is run on the SM and then the ME and is applied to only those nodes that are impacted by the most recent changes. VMs that already have the latest software and patch applicable to them are skipped in this operation. For example, if Patch 1 includes a fix for VMs of type A, and Patch 2 includes a fix for VMs of type B (but also for type A, since the patch is cumulative), then Patch 2 needs to be applied to VM types A and B if Patch 1 hasn't been applied, and only to type B if patch 1 is already present.
section.note: The tool automatically knows what nodes require patching. You have nothing to configure for the above functionality.

If a new RSV is being activated during the patch installation maintenance window and a rollback of the patch is necessary due to any issues, activate the previous RSV before starting the patch rollback.
section.p: The patching tool allows you to perform an in-service patching operation. The patching operation is done while the NCC VNF remains in-service without traffic being diverted to another NCC VNF. The tool allows you to choose up to half of the VMs within an applicable VM type group to patch at once; however, options are available to allow you control over the number of nodes to patch. For example, with a patch that is applied during the day, you may want to apply the patch to one node at a time to minimize traffic impact (although it may have a longer patch duration). On the other hand, for an in-service update that is applied during a maintenance window, you could do up to half the nodes, within each VM type and shorten the patch duration significantly. NCC automatically detects when a set of VMs are patched and back in an IS state, prior to starting the next set of VMs.

This tool can be accessed from the /opt/tpa/sbin directory on the OAME as the root user. Log in to the static IP address of either the active or standby OAME node—the tool knows which node it is to run on. The following sequence provides the workflow:

li.p: Download the single patch from Nokia.
Drop the patch on the SM OAME and run the tool.
Drop the patch on the ME OAME and run the tool.

section.p: Logs for this type of patching are aggregated on the OAME in:
The aggregated logs go to the Active OAME only.

A patch of this kind runs uncommitted and is only committed with the installation of a new patch. This uncommitted phase is to facilitate rollback of the patch at anytime after it is applied. That is, the previous installation of a patch will be committed when a new patch is applied. The previously installed patch, once committed, cannot be rolled back after it is committed. As long as the patch is not committed, it can be rolled back.

The SPS-Patching tool also contains an option to roll back the patch that you have delivered using this tool. Rollbacks are a manual operation that allow you to roll back one version. For more information about using this tool to perform a rollback, see .
section.note: Depending on the node, a re-start may or may not be required at the end of the patch installation. If a re-start is required, it will occur automatically as it has been previously configured in the patch.config file for the patch that you are installing.

Before copying any files to any NCC VMs, the user must execute the df and du Linux commands from each VM to determine the storage available and whether or not the copying of new files can proceed. Usage of the Linux commands df (abbreviation for disk free) and du (abbreviated from disk usage) can be found on every VM via the Linux manual page by using “man df” and “man du” as root user. There are two storage directories that can be used on any VM as follows:
First choice, is under the /appdata directory which is created and mounted to the cinder volume (OpenStack)/independent disk (VMware) on every VM.
Second choice, is under the /var/log directory which is created and mounted to the cinder volume (OpenStack)/independent disk (VMware) on every VM.
If there is enough storage available, proceed.
When you have completed the task, clean-up the files that are no longer needed.
If there is not enough space, either do some clean-up or contact Nokia Support.

section.title: Syntax and usage

p.b: To list the patched nodes or types:

section.p: describes the options that can be used in the command.

entry.p: Backout of the patch. The backout is always run manually. It brings the VNF back to the original state before the patch was applied.
The -f and -u options are not applicable when this option is used.
Lists the patching status for each node as the tool is running.
The -f, -s <speed>, and -u options are not applicable when this option is used.

row.entry: This option allows you to specify individual nodes in a comma-separated list (optional). The nodes can be represented by either the IP addresses or host names.

entry.p: A comma-separated list of node types (optional) to which the patch is applied. The valid types for the ME are:
The valid types for the SM are
Inapplicable types will be logged as a warning message.

A positive integer that specifies the speed of patching, meaning how many nodes in parallel that the patch can be applied to at a time for each node type. When using in-service mode, you can do from one to up to half of the number of (specified) nodes at a time.
Half of the number of (specified) nodes at a time is the default if you do not enter an integer for speed.
The url from which to grab the tar file; required by “-i”. For example,
The supported URL types are http and ftp.
The patch tar file name. The corresponding tar file must exist at /appdata/sps/patches. It is required by “-i”.

The patch file's name is in the format of <base_version>_<patch_version>.tgz. They make the patch file unique and there could be multiple patch files on a VNF. A patch is always associated with a base version, typically on any given VNF, there could be patch files that has the same base version but different patch version. It consists of two parts:

section.title: Examples of the Patching tool in use
section.p: See the following for example usages of the tool:

section.title: Example for patching operation on a system with Debug enabled
section.p: In this example, a system is patched showing the output, with debug (-d) messages enabled and the debug log displayed in the console.
Output similar to the following can be expected. Notice that you are prompted to answer if you want to proceed with the installation.

fig.codeblock:
[root@igvl95s1-oame-0 sbin]# ./install-patch -i -d -f SPS_20_0_R1_SP1_PP4.tar.gz WARNING: This tool may require a significant amount of time to run and may affect traffic and/or cause the entire site to go down. It's recommended that it be used during a maintenance window. Would you like to proceed? [y/n]: y INFO: Processing the patch file 'SPS_20_0_R1_SP1_PP4.tar.gz'. section.title: Example for a second patching operation on an IOHD
section.p: In this example, an IOHD is patched a second time showing the output, with debug messages disabled.

Output similar to the following can be expected. If this is not the first patch that you have applied, you are prompted twice to answer if you want to proceed with the installation and in the second prompt that if you do proceed, the previous installation will be committed.

fig.codeblock: [root@sps-me-oame-1 ~]# /opt/tpa/sbin/install-patch -i -f SPS_20_0_R1_SP2.tar.gz -t iohd WARNING: This tool may require a significant amount of time to run and may affect traffic and/or cause the entire site to go down. It's recommended that it be used during a maintenance window. Would you like to proceed? [y/n]: y INFO: Processing the patch file 'SPS_20_0_R1_SP1_PP4.tar.gz'. DEBUG: Patch versions = ['SP1_PP1', 'SP1_PP2', 'SP1_PP3', 'SP1_PP4'] DEBUG: Installed versions = [''] DEBUG: Previous candidates = ['SP1_PP1', 'SP1_PP2'] WARNING: If you proceed with this installation, the previous installation will be committed and cannot be backed out afterwards. Would you like to proceed? [y/n]: INFO: Committing previous installation ('SP1')... INFO: Installing patches 'SP2' in online mode. INFO: The speed for 'iohd' is set to '1'. INFO: Running installation round number '1'... INFO: Running installation round number '2'... INFO: Done.

section.p: If by chance there is an error while patching, you will receive output that indicates an error similar to the following:

fig.codeblock: [root@sps-me-oame-1 ~]# /opt/tpa/sbin/install-patch -i -f SPS_20_0_R1_SP4.tar.gz -t iohd INFO: Processing the patch file 'SPS_20_0_R1_SP4.tar.gz'. INFO: Downloading file '/appdata/sps/patches/SPS_20_0_R1_SP4.tar.gz' from 'sps-me-oame-0'... ERROR: Previous installation did not succeed or was partially applied. For a new installation to take place, the first installation must be manually backed out.

section.title: Example of running the listing command
section.p: The output of “-l” lists all VMs in the VNF, whether or not they are applicable to the target patch version. The ‘Status’ at the top is an overall status, aggregated from individual VMs.
The status can be one of:

li.p: initial: The state of the system when you begin the install operation. The patching tool is running but has not started on a particular node.
install_started: The install operation has started.
install_failed: The install operation has not succeeded.
install_succeeded: The install operation has succeeded.
install_partial: The install operation has succeeded. The patching tool has been run but some specific nodes did not finish patching and may require that the tool is run again.
backout_started: The backout operation has started.
backout_succeeded: The backout operation has succeeded.

section.p: The status transitions are explained further in the following figures:

li.p: provides a high-level example of all the patching statuses during a patching operation.
shows that in some scenarios not all of the above states need to occur during a patching operation.
shows the state transitions that can occur from a rollback or a partial install of the patch during a patching operation.

fig.title: Status transition with a patch failure example
Status transition with a rollback example

section.p: The following is an example of the results from the listing command as it is used on a progression of steps from a fresh installation, through a patching failure, and onto a successful patch.
On a fresh system install:

fig.codeblock:

section.title: Roll back of a patch
section.p: For this type of software update (patch) to be rolled back, you must perform the rollback operation manually. The patching operation can be rolled back manually to the previously applied patch or base version if this is only the first patch applied. For example, if the system is on version 20.3 and the latest patch is Patch 2 (i.e., SPS_20_3_R1_SP1_PP2) and a patch is started to 20.6 (i.e., SPS_20_6_R1_SP1_PP1), but fails and must be rolled back, that system is rolled back to 20.3 with Patch 2 re-applied.
See the following for example usages of the tool:
The tool requires that you enter the following to perform the rollback:

section.title: Example of a rollback using listing option
section.p: After a roll back, output similar to the following should be available using the “-l” option:

fig.codeblock:
[root@igvl95s1-oame-0 sbin]# ./install-patch -l Status: backout_succeeded Base Version: SPS_19_9_R1 Current Patch: None Target Patch: None Timestamp: Fri Nov 22 20:03:58 UTC 2019
------------------------------------------------------------------ HOST IP STATUS VERSION ------------------------------------------------------------------ igvl95s1-auxiliary-0 192.168.3.20 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-auxiliary-1 192.168.3.21 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-auxiliary-2 192.168.3.22 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-cdr-0 192.168.3.202 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-cdr-1 192.168.3.203 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-comsvc-0 192.168.3.182 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-comsvc-1 192.168.3.183 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-db-0 192.168.3.102 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-db-1 192.168.3.103 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-db-2 192.168.3.104 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-db-3 192.168.3.105 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-diameterapp-0 192.168.3.62 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-diameterapp-1 192.168.3.63 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-iohd-0 192.168.3.234 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-iohd-1 192.168.3.235 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-ioho-0 192.168.3.232 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-ioho-1 192.168.3.233 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-oame-0 192.168.3.10 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-oame-1 192.168.3.11 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-smapp-0 192.168.3.12 rollback_succeeded None igvl95s1-smapp-1 192.168.3.13 rollback_succeeded None ------------------------------------------------------------------

section.title: Logging examples
section.p: The following is an example of the logs produced from a patching operation:
